message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows atrial fibrillation, which is likely causing the patient’s palpitations and lightheadedness. Verapamil is chosen over nifedipine because it slows atrioventricular conduction more effectively than nifedipine. Verapamil also has negative inotropic effects, which can be beneficial in treating atrial fibrillation. Nifedipine is not typically used to treat atrial fibrillation, but rather to treat hypertension. Verapamil and nifedipine both bind to the α1 subunit of the L-type calcium channel, but verapamil also binds to the α2 subunit, which gives it additional effects on atrioventricular conduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocking agent that primarily targets the L-type calcium channels found in cardiac and smooth muscle cells. It is more effective than nifedipine in slowing atrioventricular conduction and controlling ventricular rate in patients with atrial fibrillation. Option B is incorrect because verapamil has negative inotropic effects, which can cause hypotension or heart failure. Option C is incorrect because verapamil is not typically used for blood pressure control. Option D is incorrect because both verapamil and nifedipine bind to the α1 subunit of the L-type calcium channel, but verapamil also binds to the α2 subunit.

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that slows atrioventricular conduction, making it the better choice for treating atrial fibrillation compared to nifedipine. Verapamil also has some negative inotropic effects, which can further decrease heart rate and improve atrioventricular conduction. Nifedipine is not effective in treating atrial fibrillation because it only affects the peripheral vasculature and does not have significant effects on atrioventricular conduction.

The patient's electrocardiogram shows a characteristic delta wave of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is a type of supraventricular tachycardia. Verapamil is chosen over nifedipine because it slows atrioventricular conduction more effectively, which can help terminate the tachycardia. Verapamil also has negative inotropic effects, but they are less important in treating supraventricular tachycardia. Choice D is incorrect because both verapamil and nifedipine bind to the α1 subunit of the L-type calcium channel, but verapamil also binds to the α2 subunit, which nifedipine does not.
